content: hey everyone why lock here welcome back
sorry to have been away for so long I have need in an upcoming session for a
water weird probably going into the war'll stone tunnels and there's a pool
in there with a water weird in it I don't know why this is different than a
water elemental but I imagine if I ever need one I'll just use this same model
anyways I'm gonna kick bash some parts use some hot glue for sculpting and just
make a new miniature so let's get to it gonna just go straight from the art in
the monster manual for this so it has kind of a pointed reptilian shaped head
some ridges along the back and some lashes other than that it's a big water
tentacle so actually the whole idea for this project came as I was working on
some crude carnivores for my Warhammer 40k tau army the heads are a pretty good
match for the shape so I'm gonna use one of those not sure about the spikes yet
so I'll keep those on for now and then for the body it seemed kind of tearing a
dish so I pulled out my leftover bits and started perusing just looking for
ideas and I settled on using this carapace this ribcage and two armed
talons setting all that aside for a moment
here's the base it's a 40 millimeter not a two inch but I found that I like
basing my large size creatures on these it scales well aesthetically and here's
some thick flexible metal wire sometimes you could find bubbles of this at the
crafting store in the bead section paper clip will also work so cut and Bend the
general shape of the creature and then start adding beads of hot glue until
it's as thick as you'd prefer next I attach the head and it turns out
those spikes do need to go so I chop them off and then rasped the cut area
with my knife to smooth it and then hot glue it to the body likewise the
carapace clean up the underside of that and glue it along the top and then along
the entire body not adding more glue just letting the heat of the nozzle
slightly remelt and drag it around to texture of the body so here it is so far
and then it's time to attach it to the base and texture up the base in the same
way just teasing hot glue around now these talons I attach basically where
they would be in the source image but I don't know they just didn't look right I
also decided not to use the rib cage at this point I think the angles just don't
make sense or something but since the rest of the piece is curved and it's
made of water I tore those off and then I noticed these whips in my tea rented
warriors leftover bits chopped off the arm and glued the whips in place and I
think that's much better then it's out to the garage to spray Prime I like
krylon matte painting I'm once again gonna use Vallejo who have talked about
before and they did send me these paints but again you're literally seeing them
being used in real time so I think the performance will speak for itself
I will reiterate I'm very happy with them so if you're looking for quality
miniature paints you can't go wrong I love Vallejo anyway - the airbrush few
drops of flow improver and then white and a drop or two of water mix it up
directly in the airbrush pot if you had spray primer with white then obviously
you can skip this step I only had grey on hand but the under colour is very
important for the overall vibrance of the finished model it really does matter
so these days I almost always start with a white undercoat no matter what I'm
doing so first the base colour this is
turquoise just applied solid then to that electric-blue much lighter
application and only top down in a Xenophon matter this will automatically
start to pop out all that texture and detail and finally that dark blue
hitting the ridge of the spikes the undersides of the body and maybe a few
spots for interest here it is so far gradients looking pretty nice but I want
to enrich it so army painter blue tone for as much as I love Vallejo paints I
got to say army painters washes are the best they are beautiful and I heart on
this before like that when we did the ping pong ball beholder scratch-build
I'm just gonna use them again here so this is a neat application just a soaked
brush but other than that I didn't dilute the wash just straight out of the
bottle yeah in study to liquid skill here it is wet it's gonna take about an
hour to totally dry and lastly back to that electric blue with a small dry
brush just to pick out the highlights edge highlighting would of course be the
ideal here but I rarely have the patience for edge highlighting
especially on organic looking models I usually just dry brush real real light
going around picking out the high points and the hard edges
and finally the bass rim all my D&D miniatures just get a classic black rim
now in a moment I'll show you this guy in context in the world stone tunnels
but real quick all the obnoxious youtuber 101 reminders like subscribe
reminder Bell want to support the channel totally free use my Amazon
affiliate links in the description below when you buy stuff totally transparent
to you the only difference is that I get a small kick from Amazon for having
referred you our sponsor is heroes hoard and outstanding source of models for you
3d printers out there including but not limited to Altru tiles lines and don't
miss my D&D 5th edition one-shot modules over on the DMS guild all right so
here's room 9 from the world stone tunnels from the out of the abyss
campaign so this murky pool is in the middle of this room and it splits it
into a left path that ramps upwards which I'm using my generic crags to
simulate and that goes into the tunnel beyond and the path on the right stays
at the level of the water and goes down underneath which is not shown and for
good measure here's three of the characters that are in my party so
there's a half-orc sorcerer a halfling rogue and a dragon born druid here's the
water weird pops out when they enter can command the pool as a geyser all the
notes are in the book it's a nifty little encounter good way to kill half
hour and I just love that paint such a vibrant result again white undercoat and
then using good quality paints so important so yeah I'm ready to run this
encounter next week I'm excited so relative to the source image what do you
think did I nail it or not and feel free to leave links with pictures of any kit
bashing that you've done yourself in the comments below if you like this
particular project here's two more you might want to check out also enjoy this
community showcase my LOC thanks for joining and I'll see you next time
